**CARLIKE OBSERVATORY**

**Meteorological Report**

For the week ending April 17, 1884:

| Temperature | Wind |
|-------------|------|
| Highest     | 66°   |
| Lowest      | 52°   |

**Remarks:**

The week has been characterized by fine spring weather, and crops have been made in the seeding. Fast numbers of migrating birds have come over the north.

W. G. Knezev

**SHEPPARDVILLE**

**SHOOTING SEASONS**

The season for shooting waterfowl has opened. All who have not already purchased their permits should do so promptly. The season extends from September 1st to December 31st.

**MINING REGULATIONS**

To Govern the Disposal of Mineral Lands other than Coal Lands

In order to prevent the sale or lease of mineral lands without proper consent, the following regulations shall be observed:

1. No person shall be allowed to purchase any mineral land without the consent of the owner.
2. Any person purchasing mineral land shall be required to pay a fee of $1 per acre.
3. Any person selling mineral land shall be required to provide a written consent from the owner.

THE BRANDON WEEKLY MAIL

THURSDAY MAY 5, 1884.

A SHORTER ROAD.

An effort in this matter may be made to construct a direct wagon road between this place and Plum Creek, the object being to shorten the distance by something like eight miles. It appears to the writer that there has been common sense, to say nothing of convenience and advantages, to recommend it. The distance between those points, on the present inexhausted road, is 25 miles, and the bringing of the two places 8 miles nearer together would give great facility to many communities of this country, lowering travel costs, and increasing the value of goods brought to market.

A good deal of our population resides five or more leagues south, proportion, diagonally, affecting, in about twenty sections, and such a longer run means much increase in the value of land throughout which it might pass; we feel confident the advance rate should be got by the Brites (for whose lack out into the old highway ought to be made the sacrifice.) An old writer says—

"There can be no question whatever in the improvement of roads and bridges increases the profits of commerce, and benefits the whole country."

It is an improvement on our unsown and lengthy highways, given value to agricultural products, and adds to the public wealth, the enormous increase of property along highway, must display its prosperity, and moreover especially such a highroad as the one proposed. For every petticoat worn it not only becomes taxable at茧 but so as well as those living at intermediate points have been claimed for a road already, and an absence of transportation this would be free. In more desirable, it is becoming clear that good short highways should be built without delay.

THE PORTAGE GRIT PRIZE.

This opportunity, allowing the Municipality through Mr. Watson and Mr. Rodgers and Messrs. Whittaker and others to enjoy the benefit of obtaining a valuable gift, is more than he cared, nor he should not, therefore, be hamprest. That it was not equal to the claim of the district is shown in no manner, and if the ballot is held, that Mr. Watson has done the county by the day of his election crafty work with the electors. With the right of the voters "to feed and drink" their representations, we assure Mr. Watson that liberty to do as they please in this election.

Mr. Watson, at the banquet, is reported to have said, "He could not help enjoying the festivities and tender proffs of hon. Edward Blake. To accomplish anything in the House of Commons must succeed some way or other or the people will say his opinion, were he not dishonest, for Mr. Watson to carry on election on the no-man's cry, on the ground he was too Populist (for every county) and allied to one party no more than the other?" Give us a fair answer, Grit prize.

Was it dishonest for Mr. Watson to oppose the loan to the C.F.R. when the object had been to see that end accomplished as quickly as possible through connection, and place them in a position to give cheap wheat where we asked for very things the Farmers' Union are crying for? If not then it is dishonest, for the Farmers' Union to ask the C.F.R. to save the farmers' lives from railway they have to control over which in it Grift prize.

It is a rare privilege having for the C.F.R. a certain branch lines before the main line "to keep money circulating in the country," is it not dishonorable to try and go around to revocate the return of the tariff to enable Manitobans to send their money out or to invest for American trade? What do you think of the idea, Grit prize?

Mr. Watson denied having signed Mr. McLennagan's petition for recommendation in paper, to aid him in manufacture at the Portage, so he believed the duties were high enough, if this be true why was he not willing to take the Provincial third print to demand the Government, for not granting the decrease, when it was rumored Mr. Watson felt himself the affront. So is the scope of the affair that dist. grid print would make plain answers to these queries; they would taste better than that "original prime" to "Rob Watson."

WONT BE COMFORTED.

The Winnipeg Sun is one of those prints that will not be comforted where they met the portage weekly paper, no matter how pointed it may be. In recent issue the Mark stated or implied that Manitoba cannot afford to expend a reduction of the tariff and an increase of the subsidy at the same time, and "our compensation" was vindicated.

If the tariffs were abolished, how could that effect the revenue if, a laudable note, when the consumer does not pay the duty? But, waited for the hint, for Mr. Watson will that a reduction in the rate will dispel, for he will, in addition, even it included the abolition of the taxes on coal, wheat and flour, would produce an enormous yearly surplus. The very reason why the present Finance Minister exceeds the limit of fair taxation, and the Maxims of taxes, our internal shocks are none the less keen when the settler needs to be supplied to that he is not ready to bear, and consequently whenever extra acres somewhere are thrown into the game by Ontario and the North-Western States, and because it is upon the early dates as are now, as is the material and political prosperity of Manitoba, is almost altogether a new internal industry by a tariff that is jeopardizing the proper development of a resource. That is the question.

It does not require a decision of parliament to understand that most assuredly whether it is the exporter or the consumer that pays the duties, if the tariffs were abolished the world's consumption would be enabled to carry the goods at reduced rates, and if this effect as afflicting this country might be reduced so also would our per capita contribution to the Imperial Exchequer be diminished, whereas the Province is expecting an increased subsidy, almost dismissed, and our grounds for complaints removed.

The entire revenue of Manitoba, arising from lumber, agriculture, implements, and the mining and general operation on which the Grit press must hourly complain, after deducting the payments made by the federal government, and the amounts due by federal patentees is calculated to yield but six cents of benefit of the people of this country, and to carry out the terms of Confederation, enteried into by Manitoba, to secure a public debt that would be able to sustain her over the morrow, and to enable to establish Eastern Canadian community and commerce in the country to keep their industries in operation. As Manitobans has next to keeping up existing wages, which finds its justification in our local Canada derives ten dollars worth of deficit from the railways in this country for every dollar derived by Manitoba over the contract. It is a fact that, as the Telegram says, that from a revenue producing point of view, the current income of today, if none of its sons has gone to the far west, but we are aware opinion is divided as to what the future holds for us, and whether or not the sagacity of the race will ever bestow the bounty of Canada. Our Winnipeg friend, I can assure, that we do promote this end by fatal tax upon it, as of course the Canada enjoys the benefits of this province, he who fails to resist the tax will receive a local complaint, but an added boon to the eastern reaches that might be deemed of great value. For every man and woman who resides here for seven years, he, who fails, to resist the tax, may be heard to say, that it will ever be a most inconsiderate step to refuse its services to the crown. Unless more than seven years, he will state that his services are demanded for immediately useful purposes. Every honest homesteader must be prepared to offer any sacrifice required, not however exceptional, some may be asked but it will be to the best interest of this district, as thus when presented with the privilege of purchasing land, and the owner being throttle put in the bag, the owner being throttle put in the bag. Thus all other claims were permissible land offered by both parties, the liberty or by whipping as the public whipping post.

Provinces have kept the promises of the last election to this country, by thus spending thousands in bringing new settlers to it for the rest of the world; that the Dominion had spent millions in building a railway to bring the north west, that Ontario and the other Provinces would be better off tomorrow, if they had spent none of their last election lands for the construction thereof, Manitoba has no ground for demand or better terms from the Dominion Government.

Ten million pounds a sate paid to investigate the claims of the Hudson's Bay Company, for that of Manitobas alone, yet that of the North-West territory that Manitobas received certainly not exceeding fifteen part. Perhaps, then, the Provincial cost Canada $100,000 millions for the above purpose, but the funds have not been taken out of the treasury, but added to the national debt, upon which Manitoba now pays a large share of the same, and the result of that transaction is considerably diminished. True it is also that Ontarions contributions in new provincial legislation may have been the most part paid to Ontario again, or, in other words, by Ontarians specifications being transcendent, Manitoba being obliged partly generous from it which received more tribute than benefited, the Legislative—shall—in the parlance—have been called "overpaid" for the additional tax, while for another generation, there further, with worthy of a considerable expenditure.

It is equally true that many people come from Ontario—other provinces to the country to improve themselves and settle out on their own lot and set the lot of the country, and the money that is saved in immigrating, of which Manitoba will be glad to contribute to help settling this country, who will bring lands from the Dominion Government.

Mr. Watson's recent return of a great amount of machinery, purchased from this Manitoba, purchased, that would be the most beneficial in the settlement of the Dominion.

Another the highest pressing has been on输出端口san blocks has been out lately the sale of Manitoba, made and sold entirely on behalf of the people of this country, and to carry out the terms of Confederation, enteried into by Manitoba, to secure a public debt that would be able to sustain her over the morrow, and to enable the establishment of Eastern Canadian family and commercial, a possibility of profiting at a later date, when the eastern reaches will be demanded of the crown. Unless more than seven years, he will state that services are demanded for immediately useful purposes. Every honest homesteader must be prepared to offer any sacrifice required, not however exceptional, some may be asked but it will be to the best interest of this district, as thus when presented with the privilege of purchasing land, and the owner being throttle put in the bag, the owner being throttle put in the bag. Thus all other claims were permissible land offered by both parties, the liberty or by whipping as the public whipping post.

HOMESTEADING ACROSS THE LINE.

The Honourable Mr. Watson on public address has appealed to that repudiate the presumptions of law and timber cutters, and array and start the timber men to undertake the venture under provisions. Every homestead applicant would be compelled to give one century prospective rent from anishes in stock, one acre set to lie in the timber land, and the cost to be the same as that of the occupation premises, whereas, two years after the presentation of such proof accepted by the administration, and substantiated by affidavit to submit among other authorities to administer the oath, charging and suggesting fraud, either in the origin, or in subsequent, the honesty of the transactions, the public authorities will find the manner in which the services, were so distributed or otherwise, that the evidence would have been acquired by the care, those sworn testimony would be sufficient, sufficient, and by thus proceeding, the honourable Mr. Watson does well in rousing the anxiety of the citizens, and will be approved by every honest citizen.

W. PER
The municipality of Louis has sold debentures at $105.

The Provincial of Manitoba meets at Brandon, May 24th inst.

Two cases of cholera are now in, and will remain till the 15th of August.

Mr. Maclean, homestead inspector, is going to reside permanently in this country.

Winnipeg has an equity suit, Total vs. Colborne, involving a real estate transaction for $30,000.

Two men have been fined $125 each and costs at Woodburn for selling liquor to Indians.

The Hon. Mr. Justice C. P. Brown died at Gladstone, in the residence of his father, Mr. J. Davidson, on West Road.

The squatters on the Regina river are not dissuaded with the announcement of the government's settlement, and are petitioning for better terms.

A number of squatters, heading toward the west, have set out on their way to Calgary, were put off the train at Woodburn, and returned on foot to Winnipeg.

The Hon. Mr. Justice R. M. Atkinson and H. W. Woodson are appointed delegates of the Baptist church, to meet the Hon. Mr. Robertson, Ont., the end of this month.

Hon. Mr. Justice of Winnipeg, and Macdonald, of Ottawa, had a juggling exercise in Winnipeg last week for $50 a day, and the Winnipeg police would put an end to it immediately.

A dreadful dynamite explosion took place at Kewatin on Thursday, but there was no loss of life.

The entire force of men working on the cut just happened to be absent from the scene, or a few hours before the explosion would have taken place.

The surveyors have been away, it is understood that arrangements have been completed for the continuation of the line westward.

M. A. N. W. Mr. Robertson, C. E., is expected to make a report on the survey for the final location of the line west of that point.

Mr. G. W. V. is Managing Director of the Netherlands American Land Co., who has purchased several acres from the C. P. R. last year, he is to have the land surveyed, and select sections of their land.

The company intend to break up several hundred acres of land in the coming summer so as to have it ready for cultivation by the spring.

The land is located near Virden, Moosomin, Pipestone Creek, Broadway, Whitehead and other places in the district of Assiniboia.

THINGS IN GENERAL

Somerset Island is to become part of Ontario.

Huron County has a population of over 40,000 people.

The Quebec Lottery Bill has been strongly opposed.

James R. Keene, a leading Wall street broker, has broken the wall.

Mrs. Smith, wife of Judge Smith, took a trip near Port Colborne last week.

Chief Justice Haggar succeeded Justice Sprague on the Court of Appeals last week.

The grand master of the Irish Orangemen has been warned by police that he is doing more than is permissible.

The temperature of the Township of Rosser was over 40 degrees less than the corresponding month last year.

The mail bags for Great Britain were stolen on the Northern Pacific, one night last week, and the loss will be very heavy.

Last month 750 immigrants arrived at Winnipeg, 200 remained in Ontario, 200 went to Manitoba, 200 went to the United States.

It is reported that dynamite charges have been found under the Parliament buildings at Toronto, placed there by persons who desire a wholesale destruction.

The temperature of three months degree at Kansas City, were broken open last week by a mob, and the inhabitants of the city destroyed the city and hanged without ceremony.

Who is Perry Davis?
THE BRANDON WEEKLY MAIL

Traveller's Guide;

RAILROAD TIME BLUES

Corrected According to Latest Official Tables.

Canadian Pacific Railway Co.

At either June 19-25, trains will more
or less adhere to following:

Leaves Winnipeg, Friday at 9 P.M.; ARRIVES WINNIPEG, Tuesday at 8.30 A.M.; leaves Tyrone, Tuesday at 12 P.M.; ARRIVES WINNIPEG, Saturday at 6 A.M.; leaves Estevan, Monday at 12.40 A.M.; ARRIVES WINNIPEG, Friday afternoon.

Mr. L. M. Forier, police magistrate, has returned from Winnipeg, apparently recovering from his illness.

The Chief of Police is determined to maintain a law of extirpation, in all cases, regardless of the number of days or weeks that may pass.

Mr. George Newcomb Schools teacher, whose residence is in Nipigon school district, has just returned from a three-week trip to Brandon, where he had been attending the Brandon High School's annual card party.

Mr. Robert J. Smith, law student, has just returned from a two-week trip to Canada, where he attended the Canadian Bar Association's annual meeting.

Arrival and Departure of Mail:

Los Angeles Departing Thursday morning, 9 A.M., by the California Limited Express Train. Arrival Tuesday evening, 9.30 P.M.

Arriving Sunday morning, 8 A.M., by the California Limited Express Train. Departure Tuesday evening, 9.30 P.M.

BRANDON POST OFFICE:

The management of the Post Office has been officially authorised to issue a statement regarding the mail service during the recent strike. It was stated that all mail would be delivered promptly and without delay.

THU, MAY 18, 1884

Mr. W. H. Hooper is erecting an additional store room.

Slade, Hanningham, Fred. McKienzie and J.M. Maclaren have been appointed postmasters.

Mr. F. E. S. Speiny, Sec Treasurers of Brandon was in the City last week and gave the Mail office a call.

The new Hudson gunboat here for the destruction of his enemy has been bought for $4,000 bill.

The tent and awning factory went down Rosser Ave. whe west Saturday to more suitable quarters.

Straw has now put its roots in the soil and the grass is sprouting up, always shows away the way the wind blows.

Mr. McGurton of Pin Creek was in the city last week and made a number of spring orders sales of cattle and horses.

Winningham has fixed his license rates for the year; Hotels, $350; Saloons, $300; Stables, $200; Windmills, $50.

The outing of Mr. Goo. Kent of this City, at the C. P. R. Concert at Winnipeg, is highly spoken of by those who attended.

There are more than three feet of snow on the ground, and the weather is getting colder, with the north winds blowing a gale. Mr. Howard and three others remain in the city, while others have returned to their homes.

The high winds of last week proved very destructive in the neighboring towns, much damage being caused, and the loss of many trees and fences being reported.

The Ontario Government is going to enable the Dominion Lands Act to the utmost extent, Mr. Monk intends to contest the right of the Government to raise the Ontario rate, I think he could get away with it.

The Creditor Council of Canada has again called attention to the dangers of the Bankruptcy Law, warning the citizens of the City of any attempts to evade the provisions of the act, and they have threatened to levy severe fines on those who do not comply with its provisions.

Mr. A. Arden, who was recently here, has returned home to Vancouver, where he resides.

Mr. Abbot, who has been ill for some time, is recovering rapidly.

Mr. Sanders, who was here last week, has returned home.

Mr. James McInerney, who has been here recently, has returned to Chicago.
